newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian stocks open at record highs.
newsitem.headline: Australian stocks open at record highs.

text.p: The Australian share market opened at record highs on Friday, continuing its record breaking run in the wake of a seemingly unstoppable Dow and stronger base metals prices.
The benchmark All Ordinaries index opened 5.2 points higher at 2,501.6 and by 10.15 a.m. (2315 GMT) was at 2,505.9, up 9.5 points after hitting a record and intraday high of 2,506.5.
This surpassed the previous record high of 2,500.9, reached on Thursday, February 13.
"The Dow and metals prices have given us good support," said a Sydney broker, adding that the local market's valuation was attractive value.
"We are still cheap in relative terms and so far the same stocks as yesterday are driving it."
The major miners made gains early as did the big banks in initial trade with National Australia Bank leading the pack, its shares hitting a high of A$16.70 (US$12.80).
Results continued with Perth casino owner/operator Burswood Property Trust four cents higher at A$1.69 after its 84 percent higher first half net profit of A$25.2 million.
Mt Leyshon Gold Mines, part of the Normandy Mining , group lost a cent to A$2.27 in thin trade after its 13.8 percent lower first half net profit of A$9.36 million.
Rises outnumbered falls by a ratio of about eight to three, while about 41 percent of stocks traded remained steady.
